Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Development of a broadband acoustic system for quantifying the flux of free gas in methane seeps
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this CAREER proposal the PI requests funding to develop a broadband acoustic system to quantify the depth dependent bubble size distribution and gas void fraction in methane seeps, and to measure the flux of methane gas escaping the seabed and rising through the water column. Inversion of acoustic measurements for these quantities will exploit the mechanical resonance of bubbles by observing the bubbles response at a wide range of frequencies (1-100 kHz). The acoustic system will employ a constant beamwidth transducer for much of its frequency range (10-100 kHz) in order to accurately treat bubble plumes with different size distributions that are in close spatial proximity, as is sometimes observed to happen. The system will be designed to integrate into a deepwater remotely operated vehicle (ROV) and to function at full ocean depth. A second operational mode will be established where the system can be towed from a ship of opportunity as part of a more rapid, wide-scale acoustic survey strategy. The development and use of a wideband acoustic system can directly address hypotheses about the fate and evolution of methane gas bubbles escaping the seabed. The use of the proposed system has the potential to provide transformative results including 1) refined estimates of the global flux of methane escaping the seabed, 2) increased understanding of the oceans capacity as a methane sink, and 3) estimates of the global flux of methane reaching the atmosphere from seabed seeps.

Broacer Impacts

The data provided by the proposed instrument could be of considerable benefit to the wider scientific community. Methane seeps are thought to affect ocean chemistry, ocean microbial life and atmospheric chemistry, with consequences for ocean productivity, radiation balance in the atmosphere and paleoclimate studies. Basic information on these seeps is lacking, and the proposed instrument could make a significant contribution to plugging this hole in our understanding. Several undergraduate and graduate students would benefit from the experience of helping with the development and testing of a novel device. The idea of having undergraduates do the development work for the schools echo-sounder kit is excellent. The outreach component would reach the pupils at several local schools, and has the written support of both local teachers and the New Hampshire Sea Grant. The collaborations with industry, Sea Grant, and other agencies provides evidence that the project will have a wide spread and lasting impact and that it is perceived by many other scientists as an important problem and a good approach to the problem.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Acoustic waves are an important tool for learning about a variety of processes within the ocean. These processes include the evolution of methane gas bubbles rising from the ocean seabed, and the eventual fate of that same methane gas as it rises toward the ocean surface, dissolving into the surrounding ocean water along the way and potentially reaching the atmosphere under some conditions. Methane is a potent greenhouse gas, with a large capacity for influencing earth climate, and massive amounts of methane are stored in the sediment beneath the ocean. Some of this methane routinely escapes the seabed, and it is important to quantify how much is escaping and where it is going. Taking advantage of natural resonances in gas bubbles that can be excited by acoustic waves, scientists are able to detect even very small quantities of gas bubbles in the deep ocean even when using vessel-mounted acoustic echo sounders at the ocean surface (i.e., even when the bubbles are at ranges of more than 1 km).

This project focused on developing equipment and data analysis techniques that enhance acoustic methods for observing methane gas bubbles in the ocean, with a particular focus on acoustic echo sounders that use broadband signals.  With proper data processing techniques, broadband signals can drastically increase the resolution with which individual bubbles can be resolved, which in turn allows scientists to acoustically size and count individual bubbles. The nature of this technology makes it possible to count and size bubbles both at the seabed where they are released, and as they rise into the upper ocean as the bubble size changes due to decreasing hydrostatics pressure and the exchange of gases between the bubble and the surrounding ocean water. Broadband signals can also be used to identify bubble resonance, a phenomena which is dependent on bubble size and the water depth and for which techniques exist for assessing unresolved clouds of bubbles. In developing and/or using these acoustic methodologies, including broadband acoustic transducers and associated echo sounder equipment, bubble counting techniques were demonstrated for acoustic observations of natural gas bubbles in the Arctic ocean, off the coast of California at the Coal Oil Point seep field, and off the northern coast of New Zealand.

These same broadband acoustic technologies were used to conduct a series of controlled laboratory and field tests whose purpose was examining models for acoustic backscatter from bubbles (i.e., how they are predicted to appear on an echo sounder) and models for the evolution of bubbles rising through the water column. A bubble ‘generator’ was constructed to create bubbles of similar size to those found in natural methane seeps, but composed of either pure Argon or pure Nitrogen. Both types of models (acoustic and bubble evolution) performed well for the smaller ranges of bubble sizes tested. Model uncertainty grew, however, for larger bubbles and for increasingly higher acoustic frequencies used to observe them. This uncertainty is predicted in part by the nature of large (greater than a few mm in radius) bubbles in liquids, as they become increasingly oblate spheroidal with irregular surfaces and experience a fluctuating wobble as they rise through the ocean water. It is important to note that large bubbles carry a disproportionate amount of gas. That is, a few large gas bubbles can carry the same volume of gas as many small bubbles and, accordingly, getting the ‘count’ right for large bubbles is important for accurate measurements of methane flow rates. In general, the results of this work will help guide future acoustic assessments of gas flow rate from methane gas seeps.

In parallel to the development of state-of-the-art acoustic technologies and techniques, an inexpensive echo sounder kit was developed that can enable a citizen-science approach to using acoustics for observing phenomena important to ocean science. Possibilities for using this kit are manifold, and include observations of biology (e.g., fishes, algae), marine geology (seafloor characterization), and more.
